headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. I'm Yang Yuanqing, CEO of Lenovo. Thank you for joining us. I will start with an update on our key business and the strategic items. Next, our CFO, Wong Wai Ming, will share the financial highlights. And then, our Chairman Liu will finish with some remarks. Later, our COO, Rory Read will join us to tackle operations.
Next slide. Last quarter, we continued to achieve good results across the world with all of our geos, outgrowing the market. For the fourth straight quarter, Lenovo is the fastest growing major PC company. We grew at 33% year-to-year, more than 3x  as the market rate. We had a strong growth, led to another historic high in Lenovo's worldwide market share of 10.4%, of 1.8 points year-to-year. 
Our profitability also improved significantly with our PTI of USD $102 million, an improvement of USD $37 million year-to-year. This is the first time we exceeded USD $100 million since the economic downturn, improvements coming at all geos. And particularly, I want to highlight our mature markets started contributing to our profitability. 
While strong growth in all geos was the primary factor in improving our profitability, the refinement of our lean cost structure also made key contribution. Our E/R ratio reached yet another record level since the acquisition at 8.4%, a total of 1.1 points year-to-year. In terms of volume, revenue, profitability and E/R, we've achieved outstanding performance last quarter.
Next slide. These results demonstrated that we have the right strategy and a strong execution. Our strategy provides focus, protect our leadership in China and the mature relationship to drive profitability and attack emerging markets and the global transactional sales to speed up growth. 
Last quarter, all of our geos' performance assured the effectiveness of our dual engines. Our China business is our profit engine as is our synch and the relationship of business. Meanwhile, our Idea and the transactional business, our emerging markets, our growth engine. Depending on the focus of the particular market, we use these 2 engines to complement each other and to drive balanced growth.
Our results last quarter showed that our execution is effective. What makes these results different from the past years is that all of our geos, not just in China, gained share and improved profitability. Just as importantly, we outgrew the market in all product types and customer segments. This is why although China's growth in Q2 was moderate compared to the first half of the year, overall, we still significantly outgrew the market.
Next slide. Next is about our China business, which had been very strong. By segmenting China into mature and emerging areas and applying customer tactics, we continued to expand our business in China. We grew volume by 21%, easily outpacing the market rate of 12%. This led us to grow our market-leading share up to almost 29%, a gain of 2.3 points year-to-year. Lenovo continues to sustain a wide gap with the competition. At the same time, our segment operating profit grow by USD $56 million year-to-year.
Next slide. Invest on the emerging market. Growth is our focus. Our tax strategy continues to deliver revenue growth in this regions. By fully leverage our Idea products and transactional model, we grew shipments by 65% year-to-year, more than 3x the market rate of 18%. We gained 1.8 points of the market share year-to-year to 6.4%. Particularly, we achieved the year-to-year growth in key emerging markets around the world. 
Russia reached our historical high of 8.3%, up 3.6 points. India also achieved a new record of 9.2%, up 1.9 points, and Brazil and other Latin American countries gained 1.6 points. While maintaining such a strong growth, we also improved segment operating profit by USD $3 million year-to-year.
Next slide. For mature markets, the priority is in returning to profitability and becoming a profit generator. In the last quarter, we are pleased to see that profitability improved in the mature market significantly, with a segment operating profit of $20 million, an improvement of $35 million year-to-year. In particular, North America's strong improvement in profitability was a key contributor to mature markets in terms of profitability. Even more exciting was mature markets' fast growth. 
Strong performance in both the relationship and the transactional business reached these achievements by almost 40% year-to-year, 10x faster than the market rate. This led to our highest-ever market share in mature markets since the acquisition. This is a solid momentum that we have not seen in the past 5 years since the acquisition.
We gained substantial share in several key mature markets. Germany become the first of major mature market country to achieve double-digit market share. We built the foundation for transactional sales there a few years ago, and it is now paying off with a strong growth. In Japan, Lenovo was the fastest local PC company. For the fifth straight quarter our market share reached 7%, a gain of 2 points year-to-year. North America's performance also was outstanding, with the volume increasing by 41%.
Next slide. Beyond our computing business, our new Mobile Internet business continues to grow. Since its May launch, LePhone has established a strong position in China at the high-end Internet market. The earlier screen supply problem impacted sales but this issue was relieved in later September after we introduced our latest model. 
LePhone is on track to grow according to plan. We are now increasing our efforts to grow even faster. We will invest more in marketing to drive higher volume in the next few quarters. In addition, we will increase our efforts to drive more applications and content. As an example, 2 days from now, we will hold our application developer conference in Beijing. We are committed to the mobile Internet, and we expect continued growth in this space.
Next slide. The balanced growth that we are having comes from strong execution of our strategy and our continuity investment in our competitiveness. That's why we will continue to invest to improve our innovation capability. We also will continue to optimize our business model and invest to further improve efficiency. 
One example is our recent investment in Chengdu. On this site, we housed manufacturing, research and the development and the sales operation, thereby expanding our innovation and improving our efficiency. In addition, we will invest in branding to increase our brand recognition around the world. We believe this investment will improve our long-term competitiveness and build a stronger foundation for future growth.
Next slide. Looking forward, we see both challenges and opportunities in the global economy and the industry. In terms of challenges, the global economy is still recovering, and compared to the revenue gains of the first half, the worldwide PC market is growing slower. Even the China market growth has moderated. 
However, there are also many opportunities. Commercial replacement demand is growing strong in mature markets. Emerging markets continues their rapid growth. Furthermore, we believe in the mobile Internet space, where we feel strong growth for years to come.
Our balanced growth means we are well-positioned to capitalize on these opportunities. We will invest in key priorities to drive future growth. We are confident that we will maintain our solid momentum and deliver long-lasting return to our shareholders. 
Thank you. And now, I will turn the meeting over to Wai Ming. Wai Ming, please.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Yuanqing. I will take you through Lenovo financial and operational performance for the fiscal second quarter. 
Next chart, please. Yuanqing just shared with you that we have another strong quarter, with balanced growth across geographies, customer and product segments brought by the solid execution of our strategy. Group sales in quarter 2 were at $5.76 billion, up about 41% year-to-year. PC Sales were up 36% year-to-year to $5.54 billion. Sales from the Mobile business in quarter 2 were at $217 million, up 58% year-to-year. If we compare this to its own performance last year prior to acquisition, this is also the second quarter we recorded a full quarter contribution for our Mobile business. 
Gross profit was at $593 million, up 37% year-to-year. Gross margin was 10.3% in quarter 2 compared to 10.6% in quarter 2 last fiscal year, just slightly up from 10.2% last quarter. The drop in gross margin year-to-year was primarily due to change in our business mix. The quarter-to-quarter improvement is a result of falling key component prices, as well as our strategy in growth ahead of the market to gain share. 
Operating expenses increased 24% year-to-year to $485 million. This figure has included our mobile operation expense that we did not have in the last year results. Apart from this, increase in expense was largely from increased promotional and advertising activities and employee benefit cost.  As increase in expenses was smaller than our sales growth, the operating expense to revenue ratio continued to trend down to 8.4% in quarter 2, which is another historic low level for us. 
This scaling effect helped mitigate decline in the gross margin year-to-year. Operating profit was up more than 1.5x year-to-year, but the operating margin improved to 1.9%. We have a net financial cost of $5 million, comprising the interest rate differential between deposit and interest rate and factoring cost. Pretax income was $103 million, up roughly 2.4x year-to-year, if excluding restructuring cost. 
The tax income margin improved to 1.8%. Please note that we had in last year a one-off share disposal gain of $38 million recorded under other income category. The group taxation was $25 million, and the effective tax rate was around 25%. We expect that effective rate to stay within 25% to 30% in the short term before our operating margins show a significant improvement. Accordingly, we reported a net profit of $77 million for the quarter, up 45% year-to-year. Basic EPS improved to USD $0.81 from USD $0.59 last year. The Board of Directors have today declared an interim dividend of HKD $0.26 per share. 
Now let's take a look at the balance sheet in the next chart. Our balance sheet in quarter 2 remains strong. The noncurrent asset we're around $2.7 billion, as of the end of September 2010, which was similar to our last fiscal year-end at 31st March, 2010. Current assets were around $8.3 billion against $6.2 billion in last year-end due to an increase in receivable, which was in line with the increase in our sales. 
Current liabilities were at $8.4 billion against $6.4 billion at the last year-end. The increase was largely due to increase of our payables resulting from an increase in sales and our outsourcing to ODMs. As a result, our net current liability was at $82 million in quarter 2 compared to $183 million at the end of March. 
Let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart. Net cash reserves continue to improve to $2.3 billion against $1.8 billion last year, largely due to increase in sales revenue and good cash conversion cycle performance. Our working capital management performance remains strong. Days of inventory increased 5 days year-to-year to 19 days. Day receivable increased 7 days to 28 days year-to-year. 
The increase is largely due to our continuing expansion into the emerging market, particularly consumer products through our transaction model, which tends to have longer credit period and high level of inventory. We have also increased ocean shipment to reduce cost, which also contributed to a higher inventory level. Meanwhile, we have included the mobile operation, which was not in last year's results. Typically, it has longer receivable level compared to PC. Days payable also increased 8 days to 73 days year-to-year, largely due to increase in our outsourcing to ODMs. Next, the cash conversion cycle in quarter 2 was negative 26 days against a negative 30 days last year or a negative 23 days last quarter.
Next chart, please. This chart summarizes the performance by geography. We have excluded restructuring charges and one-off items from the operating profit and margin so that you can better assess our operating results. China accounts for approximately 46% of gross sales. 
Sales in China were up 32% year-to-year to $2.6 billion or 5% quarter to quarter. PC sales were $2.4 billion up 21% year-to-year. We have recorded $217 million sales from our Mobile business, which was not in the last year results. Lenovo feature phone business continue to do well, and it has a market share of 4.7% at the end of September being  #1 local brand in the China market. Operating profit was up 39% year-to-year to $151 million and operating margin was up 5.7% from 4.8% year-to-year, and up from 5.5% quarter to quarter. Operating margin for PC business were 6.1%, up from 4.8% last year and 5.9% last quarter. 
As Yuanqing shared with you, our LePhone sales in quarter 2 was affected by the display screen shortage, but the issue is now resolved. We would therefore invest to accelerate the sales growth, and our expenses in China will likely to increase in quarter 3. Emerging markets, excluding China, accounted for approximately 18% of the gross sales.  Lenovo continues to show a strong unit shipment growth and share gains across the board in these regions. 
Sales were up 77% year-to-year or up 31% quarter to quarter. Financial performance continue to improve, and operating loss reduced by $3 million year-to-year and $8 million quarter-to-quarter. We will continue to invest in this region to drive shipment growth and market share to close to 10% in key markets, to establish optimal market position and sustainable profit in the future.
Mature markets accounted for approximately 36% of gross sales. We also recorded strong growth and share gain in all major markets in the region. Sales were up 38% year-to-year or up 13% quarter-to-quarter. All markets in the region recorded operating profit except in Western Europe. But it has reduced its operating loss quarter-to-quarter. With the continuing improvement of our business in mature market, we are pleased to report that the mature market returned to profit in quarter 2, the first time after the financial crisis at the end of 2008. The region recorded $20 million operating profit for the quarter, with an operating margin of 1%. 
Next chart, please. This chart summarizes the performance by product segments. Lenovo continues to translate strong growth momentum through our winning product portfolio. Unit shipments grew 38%, and sales were up 40% year-to-year and accounted for around 60% of our sales. Our worldwide market share increased 1.9 points year-to-year to 10.5%. We remain the fourth largest notebook player in the world. At the quarter close, Lenovo announced it has sold its 60 million ThinkPad, a milestone achievement for an iconic product. 
Desktop also performed well in quarter 2. Unit shipments and sales in our desktop were up 26% and 27% year-to-year, respectively, and has accounted for approximately 33% of our sales. Our market share in worldwide desktop market increased by 1.8 points to 10.2%, and remains third largest desktop player in the world. Our all-in-one product and our SMB targeted desktop continue to see quick growth momentum. 
Finally, mobile Products also showed strong growth during the quarter. If you compare to its performance last year, unit shipments were up 41% and sales up 38% year-to-year. Lenovo mobile feature phone business continue to show strong shipment growth at 36% year-to-year and remain the third-largest mobile player in China. 
Further to our cooperation with China Unicom in May this year, we have teamed up recently with China Telecom to further broaden our distribution coverage in China. This will help strengthen our platform  sales in the next few quarters. 
Next chart, please. I'll only give you an update of our share repurchase, which began in June this year. Lenovo repurchased 55 million shares in quarter 2 for a consideration of approximately $31 million. We have repurchased a total of 89 million in the past 2 quarters for a consideration of approximately $50 million. The average price paid for share is around HKD $4.35. We view share repurchase as one way to enhance shareholders' return. This also demonstrates management's confidence in the company's prospects. 
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you more color on the market outlook. We remain optimistic with the worldwide PC market outlook in spite of macro challenges. China market will continue to show moderate growth in quarter 3, and it is likely to continue to grow faster than the worldwide PC market. The corporate replacement demand, which has already shown strong growth momentum in the past quarter, will continue to pick up especially in mature markets and in global accounts. 
Growth momentum in the emerging markets will likely continue as we execute our share growth strategy. As the pricing of key components, such as memory chips, has come down from recent peak levels, we expect the gross margin to show gradual improvement, as we'll continue to execute our attack strategy. To drive growth in consumer and in emerging markets, we believe the scaling impact from the high volume growth will help improve our operating margin. 
In addition, we will continue to invest in R&D, branding and global supply chain, such as our new operation center in Chengdu. This will bring us sustainable future growth, although our total expense will increase in the short term. However, we will continue to manage our expenses-to-revenue ratio well and enjoy the scaling benefits. 
With a healthy balance sheet, we'll continue to be prudent in our cash management to create shareholders' value and look for M&A opportunities within the PC industry to accelerate our growth. We are confident that with our well-defined strategy and action plan in place, Lenovo will continue to improve its performance and profitability this year. 
Now, let me turn to Chairman Liu.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext:
For this quarter, the management, again, delivered an excellent quarterly report card to the board. No matter if it is the growth of shipment volume, new market share earned, control on cost or stabilization of average unit price, the substantial increase of pretax income, the report card is encouraging and is satisfying in every way. 
The highlight is the balanced development of our business in line with the Protect & Attack strategy developed by the management. Our China, mature markets and emerging markets have been growing fast, equally. I remember that during the worldwide financial crisis, Lenovo had big financial losses. One explanation provided to the board was that in that point, markets outside of China outgrew China market by 1 percentage point, and a high proportion of our business was in China. Therefore, we had big losses. 
For this quarter, China saw more moderate growth, only outgrowing markets outside of it by 2 percentage points. But this time, the results for Lenovo was totally different. The reason is simple. The management got an accurate understanding of opportunity [ph] environments, developed the Protect & Attack strategy with the right approach, balancing different deals and business lines and finally, executed the strategy with determination, which led to satisfying outcome. 
There are 3 facts which the board feels very satisfied with but are invisible in this report card. First, the management has decided to increase the investment in R&D and brand building to get prepared for future transformations in the industry. The board thought this decision was right and visionary and has offered full support for the budget. 
I believe the right decision by the board will bear fruit in the future. This year, when I gave a presentation to some investors about Lenovo's history, I made it clear on behalf of the board that we would now pursue hyper growth of profits and sharp rise of stock prices in the short term. In fact, we would move forward with firm and steady steps. We have to take a long-term view and understand that this is a marathon, not a sprint.  The management is implementing the board's decision in a decisive and innovative way, with concrete actions. We are satisfied about this. 
Secondly, we are satisfied with the way the top leadership team, LEC, led by CEO Yang Yuanqing has been working and operating. They are working in the correct and efficient way with good rapport. This leadership body has been in existence for 1 year and 9 months, operating and functioning very successfully. The work mode of the leadership team is a key for Lenovo's success. 
Thirdly, Lenovo's culture of meeting commitments, taking ownership and putting people first is being embraced and fully adopted by the whole staff. In the beginning of this year, I attended the key cusps of our major geographies. My feeling was that our employees started to have confidence in this company. Recently, I visited Europe again and attended 4 roundtable sessions with the employees there. I think we can say our employees all around the world have started to love this company. 
Some Chinese journalists who traveled together with me were surprised by one observation. There was no Chinese on our West Europe leadership team but employees there were talking about the same things, such as the company's strategy and culture in the same way as their counterparts in China. It shows that Lenovo as a global company has embarked on the right track. 
Finally, I want to say a company's performance sometimes can fluctuate due to impacts from external environments. Despite that, this company has a solid leadership team who treat themselves as owners of the company. If they have the right approach of developing strategies, complemented by the staff who love the company, plus strong corporate culture, this company will be sustainable and enduring. 
Lenovo is marching towards that direction. Thank you.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Thank you this is Gary Ng, VP Investor Relations at Lenovo. Let's now proceed to questions. In this Q&A session we have again our CEO Yuanqing, CFO Wai Ming and COO Rory Read with us. [Operator Instructions] Operator, will you please give us your instruction?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first questions come from Pranab Sharma of Daiwa Capital.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: I'd like to know a little bit about your tablet PC strategy and what is going on there and when you are likely to launch this product and what type of expectation you will have for next couple of quarters or next year for this product.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: I think what we’re seeing in this space is an introduction of some really exciting innovation. What we're seeing with LePhone and the whole mobile Internet space is really an entry into what's going to be an important segment. Where we saw the netbook phenomenon a couple of years ago, that's already begun to fade. But this mobile Internet space is going to expand. Our netbook -- no, I mean our pad solution around LePad will be introduced first here in China in the next -- early in the next quarter. And what's exciting about that, I think, is that we're building off of our number one share position in China, where we have a power brand. This allows us to enter into the market with the support and strength of our channel and around our business partners who are tailoring specific solutions around the mobile Internet for both LePhone and for LePad. I think the pad technology that will be introduced will first come in China at the beginning of next year and then, shortly after, into the second quarter around the rest of the world. But our focus here is really to take advantage of the Android marketing -- operating system and leverage what we believe is crucial: an excellent customer experience. If we introduced LePad or LePhone earlier, we believe that we have an experience that wasn't robust enough for our customers' expectation. We think at the timing that we put in place, we can deliver an excellent customer experience, combined with our channel reach and our brand positioning here in China that will leverage the base that we've created around LePhone to give that customer experience that we know that will match the expectation of those customers. That's around the time frame that we'll introduce it.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Any expectation of the number of shipment on the first one year of the launch on this product?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: No, what we're trying to do here, in this phase, just like LePhone, is to build a strong base in China, drive for double-digit share here, get scale and then begin to bring it across the planet. By leveraging our significant brand position here in China and the ecosystem that we have tailored specifically to the mobile Internet, that'll give us the basis in which to build that foundation and then expand across the planet. It's, again, build that scale and then expand across there. We think we're just at the beginning of this technology, and over the next 2 or 3 years, this space will continue to grow. But here in the initial phases, it's most important that we match the customer experience with a tailored solution that delivers to their expectation. That's what we're doing by matching up to the Android operating system delivery in this time frame.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Your next questions come from Arthur Hsieh of UBS.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: This is Arthur from UBS. I got 2 questions for you. The first question is about your China strategy. It seems to me even though you said it protect but it seems to me, it's more like an attack because China is even bigger than the emerging markets. So you just mentioned you're going to invest in Chengdu, Sichuan but I believe Lenovo already has the leading edge in the Tier 4 to Tier 6. So could you elaborate more in terms of the need to invest more in the inland region? What do you mean that you wanted to do more there, especially given that you're already leading among the competitors? That's the first question.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Yes. Very likely you're saying. So actually we think that the best defense is attack, so absolutely. So when we defined the protect, we mean we want to protect the leadership position and our profit pool. So I think we executed that strategy very well. So actually, we split our China figures by mature cases and the emerging cases. For those mature cases, we want to protect our market share. Actually, for those emergency cases, like Tier 4 to Tier 6 business, actually, we are developing the market. We are nurturing the market so that we could become the pioneer to develop the market, so to have the high market share than our competition. So this is exactly our strategy in China. That's why we not only can protect our leadership position, protect our profitability, but also we can further improve -- further gain market share and improve the profitability. In terms of the Western regions strategies, certainly. So we're not expecting that we need to develop the market. From the other side, we should fully leverage the Lenovo costs to give us more competitive position. So that's why we announced that we will build a new factory in Chengdu. So that would not just be a manufacturing facility. We also want to build our R&D center there to fully leverage the tenants in that area, to build a stronger competitive position.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: And Arthur, I'd like to add to that. These results are really all about balance. And the name of the game here is growth. By adding the 2.3 points of market share in China, building on our number one position, you can see we're rapidly expanding in all the segments, in all regions across the planet. By introducing the new plant capability in Chengdu, it gives us a competitive advantage. It opens up the West region with more effective and better cost distribution, and we need to add capacity because it's our plan to continue, and our objective to continue to grow faster than the market. This quarter, we delivered 3x the market rate growth that over 30% on a market of 10. It clearly shows Protect & Attack strategy is working. And-by adding that capacity in Chengdu, we can reach better supply chain solutions that allows us to react to customer needs more effectively and giving us better cost position and giving us an enduring competitive advantage. That's what we're after there, and that's what we're delivering.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: The next question is about the mature markets. Actually in this quarter in terms of profit improvement, mature markets has a bigger absolute dollar amount of profit improvement. So just wanted to check, the now the different countries in the mature market, what could be the biggest potential upside in the coming quarters? Because apparently, the potential there is quite significant.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Well, when we look at the mature market, what's exciting about the mature market result is for sure around the turnaround in profitability and the increased profitability. But look at the growth rate. We're seeing almost 40% growth rate across the mature market, almost 10x faster than the marketplace. And what's great about those result is we see it consistently across the consumer, the small and medium business, as well as the commercial segment. This is giving us the foundation in order to expand. And we've set a new level of market share in the mature market. We have seen market share gains in virtually all our regions across mature. And the profit is driven by our focus to gradually improve our profit quarter on quarter, on quarter. How are we driving that? We've been focused on our mix management. We've seen strong performance out of our Think group. Our Think products are being leveraged in a corporate refresh that we continue to see, move forward and actually accelerate. Our acceptance and our commercial notebook share has continued to gain and acquire new customers. And we also see a favorable component environment that allows us to deliver very good value on our highly innovative, high-quality product that the mature market creates. I think our focus is to continue to grow significantly faster in this marketplace across all regions. And it leveraged this corporate refresh to allow us to use that momentum there to make inroads in the consumer and the SMB segments as well. Our results are focused on balance, and these results today are balanced, demonstrating that Protect & Attack truly working.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Rory, just one follow-up, if I may. Because what we have heard so far from the different industry players is that in U.S., the market I think would be relatively weaker. But western Europe seems to be doing okay. But from Lenovo, we have seen a different kind of results, it seem that in Western Europe we're seeing a loss, but then U.S. is -- I mean, not just the U.S. but North America is the biggest contributor to the overall earnings improvement. So what would you say why is the results so different in terms of the different geography within the mature markets?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: I don't think the results are significantly different. What I think they are is very valid. Every one of those regions saw quarter-to-quarter improvement in their profitability. And what we saw is very strong growth rate. That growth rate across these segments has given us the base to move forward and build on it. The fact that we're seeing almost 40% growth rate on a market of 4% says, "I think we're meeting the customer needs in an effective way by delivering that high-quality innovative product at a great value."  And I think when you listen to the -- when the customers speaks, you need to listen to them. And that's what we're trying to do. Also, I highlight, we focus very significantly on building a deep relationship with our channel partners across mature. And it's really an important factor in these results. Our partners, in fact, want us to win. They're seeing a different and exciting Lenovo that's significantly gaining share. And that's the basis for that partnership to expand.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Actually, so in mature markets, commercial segment is stronger than consumer segment. So we benefited from that. We benefited from the commercial customers' replacement cycle. So from consumer segment point of view, actually we've had nothing before. Actually, we are growing faster there now in competition. So that's why from both sides, we can  gather the benefit. We are stronger than our competition.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from Joseph Ho of Daiwa Capital.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Question on the mobile business. Can you give some color on the profitability or maybe the loss about the mobile business, feature phones and LePhone on a combined basis? Just on the -- are we going to see a business unit that will come from losses and potentially into profitability in the next few quarters?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: Joseph, this is Wai Ming. I think the Lenovo Mobile business comprises of 2 parts, obviously one mobile Internet, this in the early stage. And you obviously, wouldn't expect a sort of profitable. I think in the early stage, we'll continue to invest throughout the momentum due to the target, I think, of the target market share. But on the conventional feature phone business I think we're doing very well. I think we've been growing very, very fast, I think, and profitability actually increased year-to-year.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: So on a combined basis...

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 10, 2010
componenttext: I think we can't give you sort of -- last quarter we almost sold 3 million feature phone product. It's the highest number in Lenovo Mobile feature, around $200 million revenue. So there comes a business that a couple of million of positive PTI to company. So in terms of Internet phone, we sold around 120,000 units. So it increased a little bit than the last quarter because we were still in the shortage of the screen. So we developed a replacement model. We launched the model in the end of September. So I think, October, I think we have noted supply shortages. Now, we are trying our best to increase the sales in terms of the Internet phone. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttext:
Good evening and good morning, ladies and gentlemen. I'm Wong Wai Ming, CFO of Lenovo. Thank you for joining us today. Today I'm joined by Mr. Liu Chuanzi, Chairman of Lenovo; and Mr. Yang Yuanquing, CEO of Lenovo. I will first take you through the Lenovo financial highlight for the fiscal first quarter, as well as the outlook for the year. Then, our CEO, Mr. Yang Yuanqing will give you an update on key business and strategic items that we have been focusing on this year. Our Chairman, Mr. Liu, will conclude with some remarks. After that, together with our COO, Mr. Rory Read, we'll take your questions.
Lenovo had another strong quarter in quarter 1. PC unit shipments were up around 48% year-to-year, making Lenovo one  of the fastest-growing major PC companies for the 3 straight quarters. PC sales were at $4.97 billion [ph] , up 44% year-to-year. This is also the first quarter we recorded a full quarter contribution of our mobile business after we reacquired the business. The mobile unit shipments were up 82% and sales were at $182 million, up 89% year-to-year, if we compare this to its own performance last year prior to the acquisition. This is a result of the good performance from both our conventional handset, as well as our local business. This resulted an increase in market share by 0.9 points to 4.9%, and remained the number one domestic brand in China. Such performance was much better than the projection that was made at the time of the acquisition about a year ago.
Group sales were at $5.1 billion, up about 50% year-to-year. Every selling price was down slightly year-to-year, largely due to the business shift to SMB and consumer products, especially in the emerging markets. Gross profit was at $523 million, up 39% year-to-year. Gross margin was at 10.2% in quarter 1 compared to 11% in quarter 1 last fiscal year, and down slightly from 10.4% last quarter. Our corporate strategy is to grow commercial products and relationship business to maintain our margins and at the same time, we are driving high volume growth through transaction business model rollouts to expand our SMB and consumer business, especially in emerging markets.
This will build scale and lower our cost which will help us to achieve sustainable profit in the future. The business mix shift result in decline in both ASP and gross margin in the short term. And increasing component cost as far as depreciation of key currencies such as the euro against the U.S. dollar in quarter also cost the lower gross margin. While this is a natural consequence of our high-growth strategy, we have already implemented short-term [indiscernible] as well as long-term strategy to help mitigate pressure on the gross margin. Yuanquing will elaborate more on this later. With these actions, we expect the gross margin to stabilize at this level in the short term and improve over a longer period.
Operating expenses increased 21% year-to-year, this figure has included our mobile operation expense that we did not have in last year's results, which included an investment of over $12 million in LePhone in quarter 1. As our increasing expense spending was substantially smaller than our sales growth, the operating expense through revenue ratio continued to trend down to 8.6%, which is the historic low-level for us. The scaling effect helped mitigate decline in the gross margin. Operating income was up more than 4x year-to-year, where the operating margin improved to 1.6%.
We have a net financial costs of $6 million. Pretax income was $75 million versus a $2 million loss year-to-year. Pretax income margin also improved to 1.5%. The pretax income also included the contribution of handset operation net from Lenovo Mobile, which has a stronger performance compared to the projection at the acquisition. The group taxation was at $20 million, and the effective tax rate was around 27%. We expect the effective tax rate to stay at around 30% before the operating margin shows a significant improvement. Accordingly, we reported a net profit of $55 million for the quarter. This is a substantial improvement against the $16 million loss last year. Basic profit per share also improved to USD $0.57 profit versus $0.18 loss last year. Now let's take a look at the balance sheet in the next chart.
Our balance sheet in quarter 1 remained strong. The noncurrent asset were around $2.7 billion in quarter one which is similar to last quarter. Current assets were around $7.6 billion, substantially higher than the level in the last quarter, largely due to an increase in receivable and inventory which were in line with the increase in our sales. Current liabilities were at $7.7 billion, against $6.4 billion last quarter. The increase was largely due an increase of our payable resulting from an increase in sales and our outsourcing to ODMs. As a result, we have the net current liabilities of $87 million in quarter 1. Let's go through the cash and working capital in the next chart.
Net cash reserves continue to improve to $2.2 billion against $1.4 billion last year, largely due to increase in sales revenue and cash conversion cycle performance. Our working capital management performance remained strong. Days of inventory increased 4 days year-to-year to 19 days. Days receivable also increased 6 days to 28 days year-to-year. The increase is largely due to our continued expansion into the emerging market, particularly consumer products through our transactional model, which tend to have a longer credit period and inventory level. We have also increased ocean shipment to save cost, which also resulted in high inventory level. Thirdly, we have included the mobile operation, which typically have a longer receivable period compared to PCs. The payable remains largely the same compared to last year. As a result, the cash conversion cycle in quarter 1 was negative 23 days against a negative 34 days last year or a negative 28 days last quarter. Next chart, please.
The chart summarizes the performance by geographies. We have excluded restructuring costs from the operating profit and margins so that you can better assess our results. China accounts for approximately 49% of group sales. The China PC market posted 31% year-to-year unit shipment growth during the quarter according to industry estimate, benefiting from the steady economic growth and increasing interest in notebooks. Our PC business continued to perform well in China, with unit shipments up 43% year-to-year. And we further expand our leadership position.
As I mentioned before, our mobile business also shows strong growth momentum in quarter 1. We further expanded market share by 0.9% to 4.9%, remains the number one domestic brand. Sales revenue in China were up 50% year-to-year to $2.5 billion, within which we have included $182 million sales from our mobile business during the quarter. PC sales were up $2.3 billion, up 39% year-to-year. Operating profit was up 31% year-to-year to $138 million, and operating margin was down year-to-year but flat quarter-to-quarter.
We have invested in the launch of our first smartphone during the quarter that resulted in flat operating margin from last quarter in quarter 1, but continue to invest to build a solid foundation for our smartphone business in China. In fact, the PC operating margin improved by 0.2 points quarter-to-quarter to 5.9%. Emerging markets, excluding China, accounted for approximately 16% of group sales. Lenovo continued to show strong unit shipment growth momentum at 69% year-to-year, with market share gain across the board that led to an increase of 1.4 percentage point year-to-year to 5.4%. Sales revenue in emerging markets were up around 80% year-to-year, and operating loss improved by $7 million year-to-year. Mature markets account for approximately 35% of group sales. Lenovo unit shipments in Mature Markets were up 49% year-to-year, driven by strong growth in Idea-branded products and the ongoing recovery of Think-branded products. We recorded growth and share gain in all markets in the region. And as a result, our market share increased 1.3 points year-to-year to 5.6%.
Sales revenue in mature markets were up 39% year-to-year, North America and ANZ recorded positive operating profits, Japan was close to breakeven, the Western Europe was affected by the euro depreciation against the U.S. dollars in quarter 1. We are pleased to report that the total mature market achieved breakeven in quarter 1. First time after the financial crisis at the end of 2008. Now let me give you the product performance in the next chart.
Both Think- and Idea-branded products showed strong growth momentum in quarter 1. Consumer and SMB products continued to show smaller growth as we continue to roll out the transaction business model markets outside China.
 Idea-branded products grew 74% year-to-year in unit shipments, up 74% in sales, and accounts for 35% of group sales. We have launched the first 3D multimedia notebook Y560d featuring High Def 3D technology, including a 3D screen, software and glasses. We also introduced the IdeaCentre 8700 all-in-one, a stylish multimedia consumer Desktop PC.
Think-branded products also showed good growth in unit shipments, up 29% year-to-year, and up 32% in sales. It accounts for 61% of our sales. The ongoing recovery in commercial business helped boost Think products even in mature markets. Our enriched product portfolio, including L Series for business, government and education customers, and the ThinkCentre M90z all-in-one, which is a full performance business Desktop in a 23-inch display, helped broaden our product portfolio to cater customers' specific needs. 
Notebook continued to demonstrate strong growth momentum throughout our winning portfolio. Unit shipment and sales were up 58% and 50% year-to-year, respectively. Our worldwide market share increased 2 points to 10.5%. Notebook accounts for 61% of the group sales.
Desktop also performed well in quarter 1. Unit shipments and sales in our Desktop were up 36% and 35% year-to-year, respectively. And our market share in worldwide desktop market increased by 1.7 points to 9.7%. Desktop accounted for 33% of group sales, our all-in-one product in the SMB targeted desktop continued to see good growth momentum.
Finally, Mobile products also showed strong unit shipment and sales growth. If compared to the performance prior to acquisition, were up 82% and 89% year-to-year, respectively. The launch of LePhone has received rapid and widespread customer acceptance, and the initial sales were encouraging. Next chart, please.
I want to give you an update on our recent share repurchase. Lenovo repurchased $34 million shares in quarter 1 and a total of $43 million prior to our blackout period in July. We view share repurchase as one way to enhance shareholder's return. This also demonstrate management's confidence on the company prospects. Lenovo has repurchased a total of 77 million shares for a consideration of approximately $43 million. The average price paid per share is around HKD $4.33.
Before I end my presentation, I want to give you some color on the market outlook. The worldwide PC market has shown strong growth momentum in the last several quarters, especially in China and emerging markets. Despite challenges in debt crisis, uncertainty in the face of economic growth and high compression base established last year, we remain optimistic with the worldwide PC market outlook. China market will continue to show moderate growth in quarter 2 despite slowing consumption. We will leverage our well-established core strength to further expand our leadership in China. Typical summer sales promotion in quarter 2, however, may lead to high E/R ratio in China which is the normal seasonality pattern.
The corporate replacement demand, which has already shown some growth, will be gradually picking up in mature markets. Growth in the emerging markets will likely continue as we drive our share growth strategy. Although cost pressures from key components such as memory chips and panels appear to be easing recently, the ongoing shift of product mix towards low price bands and consumer PC, especially in the emerging markets, will likely continue to exert downward pressure on the average selling price and potentially gross margin. But we already have action in place to stabilize the gross margin at around the current level.
We believe the scaling impact from the high volume growth will also help improve the operating margin over time. While having an encouraging launch of LePhone in China in May, we will continue to invest in LePhone business in order to achieve our leading market position in the Mobile Internet area. We have a healthy balance sheet. We'll continue to be prudent in our cash management to create shareholders' value and look for M&A opportunities to accelerate our growth. We are confident that our well-defined strategy and action plan in place, Lenovo will continue to improve its performance and profitability this year.
Now let me turn to Yuanqing.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. As Wai Ming has just told you, Lenovo continued its strong performance for the fifth straight quarter, building on our momentum from last year. We achieved solid results to begin the new fiscal year.
Next slide. We achieved the greater results across the world last quarter with all of our regions, outgrowing the market. This strong growth led to our historic breakthrough in the Lenovo's worldwide market share, reaching double digits at 10.2%, up nearly 2 points year-to-year. Last quarter, when I shared Lenovo's strategic goals for the new fiscal year, one of the goals was to reach double-digit shares within the year. With the effective execution of our strategy, we are pleased to achieve this goal in fiscal Q1. This is an important milestone for Lenovo. We achieved this record market share while remaining the fastest-growing top 5 PC company for the third consecutive quarter. We grow at 48% year-to-year, more than double the market growth rate of 21%. We become the number 2 for commercial notebook at the 17.1% market share, up near 3 points year-to-year. Our profitability also improved significantly with a PTI of USD $76 million. This is an improvement of USD $77 million year-to-year. While strong growth in all regions were the main driver in improving our profitability, the refinement of our lean cost structure also made key contributions. Our expense revenue 8.6% reached the lowest levels since the acquisition, a drop of 2 points year-to-year. In terms of volume, revenue, profitability and expense to revenue, we've achieved our financial targets that was set earlier this year. Next slide.
The main reason behind this performance was because we had the right strategy and strong execution. Last year, we designed our Protect & Attack strategy, protecting our leadership in China and our global commercial business, and attacking in the faster growing emerging markets and the global transactional business. The results from last year demonstrated that it was the right strategy. This year, we are continuing with this strategy. Our Think and the relationship business is our profit engine, and our Idea and the transactional business is our growth engine. Depending on the forecast of different markets, we will use these 2 engines to complement each other and to drive sustainable growth. Next slide.
Let's first take a look at our China business. In China, we further strengthened our leadership position last quarter, growing shipments by 43% year-to-year, well ahead of the market rate of 31%. This led to a market share increase of 2.4 points year-to-year. Meanwhile, our key competitor lost the shares over the past couple of quarters and we further widened the gap with them. At the same time, we further refined our end-to-end operational efficiency and optimized our product mix that will keep the current customers. Through these actions, China's profitability grew. Operating profits increased by USD $33 million year-to-year. Next slide.
In other emerging markets, the key word is growth. By fully leveraging our Idea products and the transactional model, we continued our rapid expansion, growing at almost 70% year-to-year, more than 2x market rate of 26%. We gained 1.4 points of market share year-to-year to 5.4%. We achieved a substantial year-to-year growth in all of the key emerging markets, including Russia, almost 4 points; India, 2 points; Latin America and South Asia, 1 point. Eastern Europe, slowed down a little bit but still gained 0.4 points.
At the same time, operational losses were kept at a reasonable level and were further improved by USD $7 million year-to-year. We have always believed that the key to making money in the market depends on whether you have relevance in that market. This relevance is market share and brand recognition. That is why within these emerging markets, our first priority is to quickly improve our market shares to double digit.
Next slide. In mature markets, this year, we will not only protect our relationship business, but also focus on growing the transaction business. Last quarter, we saw positive results from this strategy. In our relationship business, shipments were up 30% year-to-year, twice as fast as the market growth. Meanwhile, our transactional business, up almost 60% year-to-year, that was 4x as fast as the market. The Protect and Attack strategy within the Mature Markets delivered growth across all regions. Australia and the New Zealand gained 3.5 points, Western Europe gained 1.6 points. In Japan, where Lenovo has been the fastest-growing vendor for the past 4 quarters, we gained 2 points year-to-year. These results show the overall growth in the Mature Markets where our shipments increased by 49% year-to-year, 3x that of the market at 15%. Our market share increased by 1.3 points year-to-year reaching 5.6%. While delivering volume growth, mature markets and profitability was also improved, reaching breakeven for the first time since the global financial crisis. Segment operating profit improved by $37 million year-to-year. We haven't seen such high growth in Mature Market regions in a long time. This shows our new engines that drive our business are working. Think and the relationship driving profitability, while Idea and the transactional drive volume growth. Next slide.
Not only are we growing in our core PC business, our new business, Mobile Internet, also had a good start last quarter. Since its launch on May 17, LePhone achieved 12% market share in less than 2 months in China's high-end Internet phone market, despite the sales being slightly impacted by screen supply shortages. And the supply issue will be resolved in the near future, we believe LePhone's volume growth will increase even faster. The initial success of LePhone in the market creates a solid start for our Mobile Internet business. We will continue to invest in this area and grasp this growth opportunity. Next slide.
The success of launching LePhone was the result of several years of long-term planning and the investment in competitiveness. Looking forward, we will continue to build on our competitiveness and further focus on these few areas. The first is innovation. We believe innovation is the weapon to differentiate ourselves from our competitors. In the next few years, we will further increase our research and innovation investment in areas like Mobile Internet, digiphone and cloud computing. Second, we will continue to refine our business model and improve efficiencies across our value chain, especially in manufacturing, we will fully leverage China's push in developing its western region to optimize our manufacturing strategy and further increase our profitability. Third, we will increase our branding efforts outside of China and raise our brand recognition globally. We believe by continuously investing in our competitiveness, we will create a stronger foundation for Lenovo's long-term growth. Next slide.
Lastly, let us take a look at the market situation. It can be said that the global market outlook has both challenges and opportunities. In terms of challenges, although China is still growing faster than the rest of the world, its growth has been moderated by the slowdown in the stock and real estate markets. Meanwhile, mature markets have not fully recovered from the global economic crisis. This is especially obvious in the consumer sector where consumer confidence in Europe and the U.S. has recently weakened.
However, opportunities also exist. First, global commercial replacement demand is gradually recovering. Second, emerging markets still offer growth opportunities we can leverage. Furthermore, the Mobile Internet is growing and it will create new product categories in the business models. We already have a clear strategy in place and are prepared to grasp these opportunities. But no matter how the market evolves, Lenovo is confident that by executing our strategy and further increasing our competitiveness, we will continue to outgrow the market. Many of you may recall that before year 2009, Lenovo's market share never grew above 8%. Since last year by designing the right strategy and focusing on strong execution, our market share has been increasing rapidly and setting new record highs. Reaching 10.2% market share is an important milestone and a new starting point. Certainly, we will not be content with just this achievement. We will continue this good momentum and bring long-lasting returns for the shareholders.
Thank you, everyone. I will now turn the meeting over to Chairman Liu. Chairman Liu, please?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Aug-18-2010
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, dear friends, in earnings announcement of the last quarter of fiscal year 2009 to 2010, I explained to investors and the media, on behalf of the board, that Lenovo's outstanding achievement in the past year did not happen by chance. I told you that Lenovo had moved far away from extreme danger and had embarked on a stable, fast growth track. Now we are reporting on the first quarter of fiscal year 2010 to 2011, Lenovo achieved an excellent opening quarter based on its original plan. Here, I want to emphasize 4 points.
First, in this quarter, Lenovo's worldwide market share increased to be 10.2%, which was due to strong performance globally, not only in the China market, but also markets in developed countries, as well as emerging regions. Lenovo has a very clear strategy to determine when and where to focus on gaining shares, and when and where to focus on maintaining profits, and it executed well. It demonstrates company's strong capability of developing the right strategy and executing it.
Secondly, the significant decrease of Lenovo's expense-to-revenue ratio ensure the stable increase of its profit margin. It shows the management's deep understanding of the operation of the PC industry, as well as their excellent execution capability. In addition, with the further improvement of the company's IT system, there will be more opportunity to lower expenses while improving efficiency and performance.
Thirdly, the future increase of profits for Lenovo comes from 2 areas. First is the growth of its market share and increase in revenue. The other one is the increase of profit margin. PC has become a commodity business, maintaining profit margin will be a challenge. The fundamentals for boosting profit margin are: Innovation and the raise of brand awareness. Gradually enhanced investment in research and development is a promise for technology and innovation. For this, the management has conducted thorough analysis. A series of transformations in the IT industry such as the emergence of Mobile Internet and cloud computing have provided new space for IT companies. Despite this, in the past, numerous IT companies died or failed due to their misguided investments in R&D. These past failure cases are good lessons for us. Lenovo will pay attention to 2 things while increasing investment in R&D.
First, among various options and directions, we will make sure an exploration is in the right direction and is within our reach so that we can ensure our efficiency of investment and that we can provide and produce a strong return on that investment. Secondly, while investing in R&D, we need to make sure our other business functions and operations are equally strong. The launch and marketing of LePhone is a typical example of both of these concepts working together. In the next few years, Lenovo will work on maintaining sustainable and stable fast growth rather than just focusing on generating extremely high profits in short-term. To achieve our long-term goals, it is critical that we make efficient timely investments in R&D and build our brand.
Fourthly and finally, as I have mentioned in each earnings announcement, the fundamental for Lenovo's continuous development is an outstanding leadership team which blends talents and practices from both the East and West. This is the biggest fruit the company harvested in the last year. Because of this outstanding management team, Lenovo was able to develop the right strategy and execute it. And the leadership team has created a strong culture insight. The new global culture, highlighted by the new principle, Do what we say, Own what we do, is being embraced by employees across the world. Despite uncertainties about the world's economy and various challenges and hardships lying ahead of us, I firmly believe that Lenovo's future will be brilliant. I invite all of you to keep on tracing and checking on our progress down the road. Thank you.
