headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext:
Good evening and good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. I am Wong Wai Ming, CFO of the group. Thank you for joining us. Today, I'm joined by Mr. Liu Chuanzhi, Chairman; and Mr. Yang Yuanqing, CEO of Lenovo. 
I will first take you through Lenovo's financial highlights for the fiscal third quarter, as well as outlook for the year. Then Yuanqing will give you an update on key business and strategic issues that we have been focusing on for the rest of the year. Our Chairman, Mr. Liu, will conclude with some remarks, after which, we will take your questions. 
Let me start by giving you an overview of our quarter 3 performance on the next chart. Lenovo had another strong quarter in quarter 3 with record-high market share, the fastest growth among all key competitors, substantially improved profit and historic low expense-to-revenue ratio. 
Lenovo PC unit shipments grew 42% year-on-year in quarter 3 against the market growth rate of 17%, and we grew fastest among top 5 players. As a result, our worldwide PC market share increased by 1.6 points for approximately 9.0%. This is our record-high market share and is the third consecutive quarter we outgrew the worldwide PC market since the economic crisis. 
This was achieved by our strong growth in China and Emerging Markets and transaction business that drove our consumer business to gain market share in all regions. We also gained market share in notebooks and desktops. We improved our profitability in Q3. This is our second straight profitable quarter, supported by our profitability improvement in all regions. For expense control, this is the third consecutive quarter we have improvement in our E/R ratio and achieved a historic low E/R ratio of 9.0% through good expense management and scaling with increased volume. Yuanquing will elaborate more on how our strategy and strong execution helped deliver these results and how they will continue to help us deliver strong performance in the future as well. 
Let me turn you to details of our performance in quarter 3 in the next chart. Lenovo recorded $4.8 billion in sales in quarter 3, up 33% year-to-year. Gross profit was $531 million, up 45% year-to-year. Gross profit margin improved from 10.6% in quarter 2 to 11.1% in quarter 3. This is largely due to higher mix of notebook and high-end products, and better pricing control helped improve the sequential margin improvements. However, key component costs remained high and will probably constrain margin improvements. Although, we will continue to drive for volume growth of better scaling impact, please note that Q4 is typically a low season with low gross margin. 
Meanwhile, our actions in expense reduction are on track. We have saved a total of $247 million in the past 3 quarters. We further reduced our operating expenses from $457 million to $431 million year-on-year in quarter 3. The strong sales volume increase in quarter 3 helped achieve better scaling expenses, resulting in our expense-to-revenue ratio to further improve to a historic low of 9.0% in quarter 3 against 9.5% in quarter 2. 
Notwithstanding that we have already achieved the majority of our target expense reduction in the last 3 quarters as planned, we will continue our efforts in expense control. We will also invest part of the savings to drive future growth opportunities in consumer business, R&D and in Emerging Markets. We expect the E/R ratio to remain low, although E/R ratio in quarter 4 is usually higher compared to quarter 3 due to the seasonality. We have a strong operating profit in quarter 3. This the second consecutive quarter we returned to profit with improved margins. 
Operating profit was $99 million. We recorded a nonoperating expense of $6 million, which relates to net financing costs. Pretax income was $93 million. We recorded some one-off items in Q3. There were provisions of non-reimbursable warranty costs for replacing components and parts and licensing fees that resulted an expense of $43 million. The group has recorded a net gain of $43 million from disposal of some of our investments during the quarter. As a result, our pretax income for quarter 3 is $94 million. Profit attributable to equity holders for quarter 3 was $80 million. EPS is USD $0.86 in this quarter. 
Next chart, please. Our balance sheet at the end of December remains strong. The noncurrent assets were approximately $2.5 billion. Current assets were around $6.9 billion against $4.1 billion as at March 31, 2009. The increase in trade and notes receivable was roughly in line with our sales increase. The current liabilities were at $6.8 billion against $4.4 billion as of March 31, 2009. The increase was largely due to increase in our accounts payable. And again, this is in line with our growth in business. As a result, we have net current assets of $17 million as of December 31 against $319 million net current liabilities recorded at the last fiscal year-end date. 
Let's go through to the cash and working capital in the next chart. Cash reserves continued to improve to $3 billion against $2.4 billion last quarter, while our bank borrowings were $597 million, similar to last quarter. Our net cash reserve remained very healthy at $2.4 billion at the end of the quarter. We continue to do well in managing our working capital. Compared to last quarter, days receivable were 24 days, which shows an improvement of 11 day year-on-year. This was achieved through reduced overdue accounts receivable balances and early payment incentives. Days inventory also showed the reduction of 2 days year-on-year to 15 days, which was driven by strong sales performance. Day payable was slightly down by 3 days year-on-year. As a result, the cash conversion cycle in quarter 3 was at negative 32 days, decreased or better by 10 days year-on-year. 
Next chart, please. China. China continued to deliver solid growth and gain share amidst keen competition. Robust growth of the China market was driven by consumer products, especially notebook. The China PC market posted 41% year-on-year growth during the quarter, benefiting from steady economic growth under the government stimulus package, improved consumer sentiment and increasing interest in consumer notebooks. We continue to expand our leadership in China by growing 54% in unit shipments and increase our market share by 2.8 points to approximately 33.5% based on the latest industry estimates. This is the largest quarterly increase in share in the last 9 years. We have the highest market share in our history. The impact of the government rural subsidy program, as we mentioned in previous quarters, remains more in quarter 3. But we believe the huge rural population will be a big potential market in the future. 
Sales were up 45% year-on-year and up 14% quarter-for-quarter. Operating profit was $135 million and operating margin improved from 4.8% in quarter 2 to 6% in quarter 3. The margin improvement was due to a higher mix of notebook and high-end products and better pricing control, as well as high attachment rates of services, software and peripherals. 
Emerging Markets, excluding China. Our expansion in Emerging Markets continue to show good momentum in quarter 3. Lenovo grew 52% year-over-year by unit shipments, again, 19% market growth. We gained share in almost across the region. As a result, our market share was up 1.2 points to 5.5%. Sales were 53% year-on-year and up 39% quarter-to-quarter. Profitability in all markets in the regions improved year-on-year, except Latin America, and operating loss was reduced from $20 million to $6 million in this quarter. Operating margin was improved accordingly. 
Mature Markets. Mature Markets are on track to turn around. Unit shipments grew modestly compared to Emerging Market at 16% year-on-year against the market growth of 10%. We gained share in all markets, except North America, as our consumer business was still relatively small in this market. Unit shipment in North America and Western Europe were up 17% and 7% year-on-year respectively.  Western Europe, Australia and New Zealand were profitable in quarter 3. North America was breakeven. Japan recorded a strong shipment unit growth at 46% year-on-year. Indeed, we have recorded the fastest growth for the 2 straight quarters in Japan and the #1 in consumer business growth in quarter 3. Japan was approaching break-even level in quarter 3 as well. Operating loss reduced from $15 million last quarter to $7 million this quarter. Indeed, if we look at the operating profit before headquarter and other expense allocation, the Mature Markets have already recorded a small profit after 6 quarters of losses. These are the results of the improved margin control and our expansion in the transactional business, which helped to increase our business resulting a better scaling impact. This U.S. dollar weakening against key currency also helped margins, especially in Europe and Canada. 
Next chart, please. On product performance, Lenovo posted share gain in both desktop and notebook computer markets in quarter 3. The launch of Windows 7 helped improve the PC market during the quarter. Notebook shipments in quarter 3 were up 68% year-on-year against 32% market growth, and we gained market share in notebook worldwide to 8.5%.  Revenue was up 46% year-on-year, which was largely due to our expanded consumer product lineup. Notebook continued to be the largest contributor to the company's total revenue, accounting for approximately 62%. Our Idea netbook has contributed to the good notebook volume growth that stabilizes approximately 50% of our net notebook business, similar to last quarter. During the quarter, we launched the industry's first multitouch capacitive tablet booklet S10-3t. Our Desktop shipments were up 18% year-on-year in the quarter against minus 1% market growth, boosted by the strong consumer products. We gained market share in Desktop worldwide to 9.9%. Revenue was up 17% year-on-year, accounting for 36% of our total revenue. 
Please turn to the next page for the outlook. While the worldwide PC market has shown signs of improvement, commercial spending still remains soft in quarter 3, though, it is expected that the corporate replacement cycle may come in the second half of this year. Our expansion in consumer and Emerging Markets delivered good momentum in quarter 3, and we will continue to invest in this area to drive growth. 
However, the ongoing shift of product mix towards consumer PCs and penetration into Emerging Markets may exert pressure on the ASP. But we think that the ASP may remain relatively stable in quarter 4 compared to quarter 3. However, the supplies issue in certain key components that impacted us in quarter 3 will continue to constrain margin improvement. And particularly, in quarter 4, which is typically low season and E/R ratio, therefore, were normally higher sequentially compared to quarter 3. 
In addition, we will continue to take expense out in order to achieve a more efficient operation. The volatility of major currency against U.S. dollar will also have impact on our margins, especially in the Mature Markets, though we have a prudent hedging policy in place. Despite these and sequential seasonality, we expect the year-on-year unit shipment growth in quarter 4 is similar to quarter 3. 
The progress in quarter 3 continues to demonstrate the strength of our strategic priorities, and we will continue the solid execution to drive consistent strong performance. Yuanqing will give you more update on these later. 
Now let me turn to Yuanqing.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext:
Thank you, Wai Ming. Hello, everyone. Today, I will first give you some comment on our performance last quarter, and then I'll discuss our view and the thinking on the future. 
Next slide, please. Overall, we continued our strong momentum in the third quarter. For the first time since our acquisition of IBM PC business 5 years ago, Lenovo become the fastest-growing PC company at 42% year-to-year, vastly outpacing the market growth rate of 17%. This record growth enabled Lenovo to achieve its highest-ever global market share for the third straight quarter, reaching 9%. Our growth was driven by gains in almost all regions of the world, particularly in China and other Emerging Markets. And the continued rollout of our global transactional business is another driver. 
Last quarter, Lenovo continued to expand its leadership position in China, gaining 2.8 points to reach our all-time high share of 33.5%. Our expansion into Emerging Markets outside of China continued to yield strong results, growing at 52% year-to-year, greatly outpacing the market rate of 19%. With this strong growth, Lenovo gained 1.2 points of the market share year-to-year. We grew volume  radically year-to-year in key markets, such as India at 54%, Southeast Asia at 66%. Eastern Europe at 63%, and Russia at 374%. We also saw our growth in most regions of the Mature Market. Overall, we gained 0.2 points of the share year-to-year. But in particular, Japan gained 1.5 points, Australia/New Zealand gained 1.7 points and Western Europe gained 0.3 points. 
Meanwhile, the expansion of our transactional model is becoming an important driver in the company's market share growth. In this space, we gained 1.6 points of the market share worldwide year-to-year. This includes gaining 1.6 points in Emerging Markets outside of China and 0.5 point of share in Mature Markets. This strong performance proves that our attack portion of our strategy, which was clarified last year, is delivering good results. 
Next slide, please. We have sustained the momentum that returned Lenovo to profitability last quarter and grew our PTI to USD $94 million in the third quarter. We improved our profitability in every part of the world and our strong performance in China played a especially important role. Our China business contributed USD $135 million to our profitability, up 42% quarter-to-quarter. We achieved this by not only increasing sales volume but also focusing on improving average sales price and gross margins. In other Emerging Markets, our profitability improved USD $14 million quarter-to-quarter. In Mature Markets, our profitability are improved by USD $8 million quarter-to-quarter, bringing our Mature Markets growth close to breakeven. 
Next slide, please. The improvement in profitability was also a result of our effective expense management after achieving our lowest E/R ratio since the acquisition in fiscal Q2. Last quarter, we reduced the expenses by USD $26 million year-to-year, while we grew our revenues by 33%. Our efforts led to another historical low E/R ratio of 9%. Meanwhile, we continued to focus on managing costs. We lowered our cost-per-box by 4.5% quarter-to-quarter. 
Next slide. These strong results, once again, demonstrated that we have said are effective strategy with strong execution. Early last year, we set a new business strategy based on the market conditions at that time and the company's situation. We called this strategy Protect and Attack. Protect our core businesses in China and in global commercial segment and attack Emerging Markets and the global transactional segments. So this strategy is simple and clear and enables every team to focus on their key areas. 
Based on this strategy, we realigned our organizational structure. Mature and the Emerging Markets growth at the front end and the Think and the Idea product growth at the back end. This structure is more efficient and effective, allowing better integration and a greater focus on the customers' needs. Catering to our different customer needs, we launched different lines of innovative products in the commercial and the consumer segments. This enhanced our product lines, making them more complete and more competitive than ever before. Meanwhile, our culture of delivering our commitments is taking hold across our teams and they're delivering strong results. 
Next slide. Here, I would like to share more of thoughts on this industry, and the Lenovo's business philosophy. As this industry moves toward low price points, more and more manufacturers think that there's no room or need for innovation. These PC players create a commodity products in order to achieve higher efficiency. But at Lenovo, we have a different perspective. Now we believe that efficiency is important in the industry. Without it, you cannot survive. But innovation is equally important. Room for innovation is everywhere. We need to be a company that best balances between innovation and the efficiency. And usually, this is the most efficient innovation to lead the developments in the industry. 
Guided by this philosophy, we were able to fully demonstrate our innovation capability and achieve greater results at this January's Consumer Electronic Show. In only 3 days, we introduced more than 20 new products that enhance our strong portfolio. This has not only further expanded our product line but also opened new areas that can ensure Lenovo's sustainable growth. These products got a greater response, as Lenovo won 8 industry awards, and the most of any PC manufacturers. We also generated a positive media coverage in more than 3,500 articles worldwide. Our success at the CES demonstrates our innovation leadership. Even more, it further proves that Lenovo has a strategic vision to identify growth opportunities and the capability to grasp at these opportunities. 
Next slide. One of the growth opportunities that we see, in the Mobile Internet. As 3G networks become more mature, cloud computing technologies become more prevalent, content and the usage models of the Internet become more diverse. Traditional PCs such as desktop or notebook, no longer fully satisfy the people's needs to connect online at any time and any place. Consumers are eager to get smaller and better wireless devices that they integrate with the Internet content and the services and they easily connect to 3G or WiFi networks. Such a need is especially evident for an Emerging Market like China. Targeting this growth opportunity, we have defined Lenovo's Mobile Internet strategy. 
To dedicate our efforts in the development of more advanced and a complete line of Mobile Internet devices, these devices can integrate with and will be best assured for the most popular Internet applications. Therefore, they will provide the users with optimal Internet experience. Based on this strategy, we have been carefully preparing our technology and the product portfolio for the past few years. 
At CES, we introduced the first wave of our products in 3 categories for the Mobile Internet. Our first smartphone, LePhone, and the industry's first ARM-based smartbook, Skylight, and the IdeaPad U1, our traditional notebook and our tablet hybrid PC. These products become instant stars after they were announced. Many people can't wait to buy and start using them. We will first launch this new business in China because there, we have a strong brand and a channel network. With these advantages, we can more easily integrate it with the service providers and the carriers. 
In addition, with the shareholders' approval of our recent acquisition of Lenovo Mobile, it further strengthens our end-to-end operational expertise in phone and small form factor devices. We believe that the Lenovo's Mobile Internet products will have high potential. 
Next slide. We are seeing good momentum in our performance and making progress with our new business. While we will make our best efforts in maintaining this momentum, challenges clearly remain. First, fiscal Q4 is typically the slowest season of the year. Seasonality will continue to be a factor. Second, although the global economy has shown signs of improvement, the corporate replacement cycle is still expected to be delayed until the second half of this year. In addition, although we have strong plans and the processes in place to manage and minimize the supply issue, component costs are increasing, especially memory, and remain a challenge. And more importantly, I would like to emphasize that we will continue to invest heavily in Emerging Markets, in consumer business and in the Mobile Internet to achieve sustainable growth. We believe that long-term benefits of this investment strategy are clear. 
Next slide. In any case, I have complete confidence in Lenovo's future innovation. Good results depends on our strong strategy and our solid execution, one step at a time. To do this, we must continue to focus on executing our strategy priorities: maintain our China leadership and improve profitability; improve profitability in Mature Markets; continue to invest in and seize growth opportunities in Emerging Markets and the global transactional segments; execute our Mobile Internet strategy, firstly in China then worldwide; drive our lean cost structure; differentiate this through innovation and our leading product portfolio. 
Thank you, everyone. Now I will turn the meeting over to Chairman Liu.

So we're selling additional breath and additional scope, which gives us a more robust portfolio to react to customer needs.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Well, actually you could see the numbers, the growth in the last quarters of how much comes from the Emerging Market, how much -- what percentage comes from the Emerging Market, what percentage comes from the Idea product, what percentage comes from transactional business. So that's very compelling.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Yes, maybe I'll give you a sweep of the numbers that actually would demonstrate, I think, the result of execution of our strategy. I think let's look at the sort of Emerging Market and Mature Market. I think year-to-year, we increased $1.2 billion turnover, 82% come out from Emerging Markets. I think the rest come out from Mature Market. And if you look at -- if you really break down between Idea and Think, year-to-year, it was an increase of $1.2 billion, nearly 70% come out from Idea, about 30% comes out from Think. And I just said that transactional and relationship business, more than 90%, 9-0, coming from transactions, the rest coming from relationship. Now looking at quarter-to-quarter, I think we increased turnover by about $690 million or $685 million, above 36% coming from Emerging Markets. And if you look at Think versus Idea, Idea, I think, account for about 40%, and you can actually see more sort of transaction business also coming from Think as well. I mean, don't just take Think as a commercial relationship business. And if you look at the [indiscernible] of transaction versus relationship, 75% quarter-to-quarter come out from transaction and the balance from relationship. And then you can see that, I think, our success closely tied with the successful increase in the transactional business at the Emerging Markets.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

componenttext: Right. I need to find out -- I think that I -- well, if you have a second question, I think, proceed first. I would need to find out because we have the overall growth notebook. But I need to find out what China notebook shipped.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Yes, absolutely. We should and we could further improve our SMB segment business in China, particularly in those matured cities. But meanwhile, we should -- so we have a lot of opportunity, small city and small towns because there are many, many SMB business in those cities. So now we separate the cities, mature cities and emerging cities in China to adopt the different strategies to attack the SMB and the consumer business. So we believe these kind of actions will help. So we believe we could get more market share from the SMB business in China.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Also Arthur, it's very interesting is if you look at some of the product innovation with the new ThinkPad Edge product that we've announced in the most recent quarter, we see very strong interest in the SMB segment around this product, initially in the 13-inch form factor. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

componenttext: Could you say it again? Connection wasn't very good.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Notebook continues to grow dramatically faster.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Yes. Another question is about this component shortage into this quarter. It's kind of hard to believe that given this is actually a weak quarter, right? So isn't the price supposed to ease, given the demand is slowing down?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Well, actually, the demand that was so strong in 4Q on a global basis, I think, it drained most of the inventory on the part. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: And my final question is about the inventory situation. I think apparently, you guys did a really good job reducing the inventory days to only 15 days. Any idea about the inventories among these retailer, distributors in different regions? What's the status now, say, comparing with normal level?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: We manage this on a day-to-day and a weekly basis. So all of our data across all regions are all within our normal management SKUs. We were trending very consistent to where we expect to be and within our normal inventory levels, even with the significant increase in volume activity. So nothing unusual around the inventory levels. We're seeing strong selling and strong sell-through. And business activity seems very consistent with the inventory levels we would expect.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Patrick Yau from Macquarie.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: I actually have 2 questions. The first question is with regards to the expected level of seasonality in the current quarter. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the reason why that question is coming around is because you are exhibiting a fairly strong momentum as far as share gains are concerned. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: You mean either year?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: That is not -- we do not expect that.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: No, actually, our quality trends continue to look very strong. Our focus on innovation and quality remains very consistent. But our overall trend is really quite good.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Your next question comes from Eve Jung from Citi.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: My first question is that you delivered an 18% of desktop shipment growth for December quarter. Which area of settlements did you see particularly strong desktop shipments? And also, all-in-one PCs, what's the sales mix in your desktop shipments right now? And will it continue to trend up? That's my first question.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Yes, so I'll take the second question first. The all-in-one areas, one good example of innovation that helped drive growth for us, the Idea product group implemented the all-in-one, now Think has come out of it as well. Our products are quite innovative, they're quite stylish. We've seen a very rapid uptake in that part of the desktop market. And in several segments, we've taken significant share position in the all-in-one segment. So that's been very encouraging. And we'll look to continue to expand that all-in-one percentage of across the Desktop segment. In terms of Desktop, we continue to see Desktop activity. I think that a number of our competitors have neglected the Desktop space. We continue to innovate and create new products to meet customer demand. And while that market is not growing as rapidly as notebook, we've been able to gather and gain a share. We've seen that in most Emerging Markets, and we've seen that across most key segments.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: And also regarding E/R ratio, can you provide us your E/R ratio internal operations? And also what's a likely break-even schedule for Emerging Market and the U.S. market?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Well, we normally do not actually sort of break it down. But I can show you that China probably has the lowest E/R ratio within the group. I think it will be very -- we believe that we are the lowest within the industry.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Yes, we're very encouraged by the E/R activity. We've had an intense focus on managing expense. We'll continue that focus even as we're growing revenue, want to make sure that we're getting more and more cost-effective, being more efficient and more productive. That will not change. We will continue to drive hard on the expense side and continue to make our business model more and more competitive. China is clearly a leader in that segment, but this is a trend that we're seeing across our business in all key segments.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Not only we had a very good E/R ratio in China now, our E/R ratio in Emerging Market is competitive as well. So I think we are well executing our strategy to replicate our business model, to replicate our cost structure from China to other Emerging Market. So we are executing this strategy very well.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Due to a time constraint, we will welcome the last question.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: I think there are 2 -- one investor concerns is about China. And you clearly delivered good results this quarter. headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: I think in China, we are pretty strong, in lodging [ph] the price in the public segment. So we dominate this segment. And also I think we are very strong in consumer area. So I believe with this kind of strategy, we could further strengthen our leadership position in China.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: Okay. And have you -- in this SMB market, who is the major competitor there?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: We have already had a lot of discussions with those carriers in China, but we cannot have detailed information to share with you now.

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: I see. Last question is on the ASP trend in the current quarter. Will that stabilize, given the component price is pretty high right now on a sequential basis?

headline: Lenovo Group Ltd., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-04-2010
componenttext: We were actually -- in the most recent -- in quarter we're reporting, we actually saw ASP trend up slightly, which is a first time in 5 quarters. We think that was -- we know that's driven by mix and improving economic environment. We've also seen the expansion in the netbook space as now kind of stabilizing out, and we are reaching kind of a normal level there. I expect that there will be ASP pressure as we move forward. That's an industry phenomena. But I think it's clearly moderating, and I think you'll see a period of more consistent or stable ASP trending and won't be anything significant out of the historical norms.
